bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to George Miller Sternberg, June 29, 1893

div1.p: Reed is honored to be accepted into the Army Medical School and assures Sternberg that no one will work as hard as he will for the good of the School and Corps. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to George Miller Sternberg, June 29, 1893
div1.opener:
Headquarters Department of Dakota,
ATTENDING SURGEON'S OFFICE,
St. Paul, Minn., June 29, 1893
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Upon the receipt
of Dr. Merrill's very kind let-
ter of the 17th Inst., I, at once,
replied expressing my grat=
ification over the good
news contained therein,
and my gratitude to the
Surgeon General for his ex=
pression of confidence in
me as a working member
of the Corps.

As the news
had come through Dr.
Merrill, I did not know
whether it would be prop=
er for me to write a
personal letter to the
Surgeon General under the
circumstances; (Col. Alden thought
not,) but the announcement
in the morning's paper if
the faculty of the Army Med=
-ical School removes any
scruples which I might otherwise
feel, and impels me to
tell you how very much
I appreciate this honor.
Although I shall be one
of the least worthy members
of the school, yet I can assure you
that no one will work with greater
zeal for the good of the school and Corps than
myself.
div1.closer:
Very Sincerely, yours, Walter Reed, To
Surgeon Gen.l
Geo. M. Sternberg, U.S.A.
Washington, D.C.
